importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article publication indicates the most recent update on Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, marking a significant advancement in national space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-month calibration period for the H1 satellite suggests that full operational capability is expected by early 2026, placing the key utilization of the satellite within this timeframe.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space program.
The launch was conducted by SUPARCO from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral technology allows detection of subtle material and chemical changes on Earth’s surface, enabling advanced monitoring of crop health, water resources, and disaster impacts.
The satellite is expected to enhance national capacity in agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
The launch is seen as a strategic component of Pakistan’s broader space ambitions and reflects its partnership with China in peaceful space exploration.
The mission supports development initiatives such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), particularly in infrastructure and geohazard risk assessment.
Two other satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) are already fully operational, indicating a growing momentum in Pakistan’s space capabilities.
It may take about two months to calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational, with full operational status expected by early 2026.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the nation launching its first hyperspectral satellite, signifying a critical step in national technological and scientific development, especially in agriculture and disaster management.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is responsible for the development, launch, and management of Pakistan’s space missions, including the H1 satellite, making it central to the achievement of national space goals.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite enables advanced Earth observation capabilities that traditional satellites lack, allowing for precision monitoring of crops, water, and environmental hazards.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A satellite launch site in China’s northwest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site in China is relevant because it highlights Pakistan’s collaboration with China in space technology and launch operations, underlining a strategic partnership.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China provided the launch infrastructure, reflecting a strategic space cooperation between Pakistan and China, strengthening bilateral ties and enabling access to space technology.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure initiative linking China’s Xinjiang to Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral data from H1 will support geohazard risk assessment and sustainable development within CPEC, enhancing infrastructure planning and environmental safety.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other operational Pakistani satellites in orbit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their existing operational status shows that Pakistan’s space program is advancing rapidly, with multiple satellites now functioning, increasing national space capabilities.

namedEntities.name: Muhammad Yousuf Khan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key figure in the announcement of the H1 satellite’s success and its potential to revolutionize agriculture and natural resource management.

namedEntities.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s government ministry responsible for international relations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ministry highlighted the strategic partnership with China and the broader socioeconomic benefits of space technology, underscoring diplomacy and development synergy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a significant milestone in its space program. The satellite, developed by SUPARCO, uses advanced hyperspectral technology to detect subtle material changes on Earth, enabling improved monitoring of agriculture, water resources, and disaster risks. The launch is part of a broader effort to strengthen national capabilities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, and infrastructure development—particularly within the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While the satellite requires about two months of calibration before full operation, it reflects Pakistan’s growing space ambitions and deepening strategic partnership with China. Two other satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) are already operational, indicating a rapidly expanding national space program.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
